(CASTELLANO) Un pequeño favor es de esas películas que parecen una cosa, luego otra, y al final... ninguna de las dos. Pero eso no es necesariamente malo. De hecho, ahí está parte de su encanto. Paul Feig firma una comedia negra con toques de thriller que, aunque no sea perfecta, resulta muy entretenida y visualmente deliciosa. Desde el primer minuto, Anna Kendrick se gana tu simpatía. Está divertidísima, natural y llena de chispa. Y aunque Blake Lively puede caer mal fuera de la pantalla, lo cierto es que aquí borda su papel. La historia juega con los clichés de la mujer perfecta, los secretos inconfesables y los giros que buscan dejarte con la boca abierta. Algunos funcionan mejor que otros, pero en conjunto se mantiene el interés. Es cierto que en la parte final se estira un poco más de la cuenta, como si no supiera muy bien cómo rematar tanta locura, pero aún así el conjunto se sostiene gracias a su tono desenfadado y al carisma de sus protagonistas. También destaca la estética cuidada: vestuario, fotografía y música juegan a favor de esa mezcla de sofisticación y humor retorcido que hace que Un pequeño favor no sea una más del montón. No llega a ser un clásico del género, pero es una opción muy apetecible para pasar un buen rato. Con una copa de vino en la mano, entra todavía mejor. Y por cierto, me encanta la canción Laisse tomber les filles de France Gall. Aquí suena de maravilla. (ENGLISH) A Simple Favor is one of those films that seems like one thing, then becomes another, and ends up being... neither. But that’s not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, that’s part of its charm. Paul Feig delivers a dark comedy with a touch of thriller that, while not perfect, is quite entertaining and visually delightful. From the first minute, Anna Kendrick wins you over. She’s funny, natural, and full of spark. And even if Blake Lively might rub some people the wrong way off-screen, here she absolutely nails the role. The story plays with clichés about the perfect woman, hidden secrets, and twists designed to keep you guessing. Some land better than others, but overall, it holds your interest. It’s true the ending stretches things a bit, as if unsure how to tie up all the chaos, but it still holds together thanks to its playful tone and the charm of its leads. The film also shines in its visual presentation: costume design, cinematography, and music all enhance that mix of sophistication and twisted humor, making A Simple Favor stand out from the crowd. It may not be a genre classic, but it's definitely a stylish and enjoyable ride. And with a glass of wine in hand, it goes down even smoother. And by the way, I absolutely love the song Laisse tomber les filles by France Gall. It fits perfectly here.

A Simple Favor - 8/10. I always glanced over watching this over the years, but finally, got time to watch it. And with all the news surrounding the sequel, and the supposed feud between the stars, it made me want to watch this more ironically. Think of this as a messier version of Gone Girl, but with some cheesy noir flavour. This happened to be Paul Feig’s first deviation from straight forward comedy, and he does a good job here. You can tell he had fun making this movie. And as for the stars, with the context that I have now, watching this I can tell where exactly they probably started hating each other. This surprisingly is probably Lively’s best role she’s done, and she’s kinda a shadow of a character here (she’s not in it as much as I thought). Anna Kendrick is great as ever, and though this might be bias of me to say as a fan of hers: she’s the heart of this movie in my opinion. What works for this movie is that it just seems to playfully work with the material it has at hand. Its not trying to be a serious and straightforward twisted look at its respective story, but rather, has a darkishly light touch through its twists. Though I feel it does falter when Blake’s character’s reveal is that she’s a twin, its still a fun watch and one that will burn through time with ease. Good movie and a fun one at that!

Filme: Um Pequeno Favor Assistido: Ago/24 Elenco: @annakendrick47 @blakelively @henrygolding @lindacardellini Modelo: #suspense #crime Duração: 2h Ano: 2019 Minha opinião: Temos como protagonista Blake Lively (esposa do Deadpool) e Anna Kendrick. E temos Henry Golding fazendo papel de esposo de Emily (Blake). Um suspense onde temos Stephane (Kendrick) uma mãe que tem filho e que faz amizade com o filho da Emily. E criam uma amizade. Até o dia que Emily desaparece e é dada como morta. Com isso Stephane começa a ter um romance com Sean o viúvo da Emily. Até o momento que o filho da Emily diz que viu a mãe. Até que descobre que Emily estava armando o bote para receber o seguro de vida. E o desfecho descobre quem Emily estava viva e quem morreu foi sua irmã gêmea que Emily matou e tomou seu lugar. Até o final que tudo é descoberto. Temos uma interpretação boas, mas o filme não foi aquele estouro. Mesmo com o charme e sensualidade de Blake. Não foi como “Instinto Selvagem” com Sharon Stone e Michael Douglas. Roteiro e enredo são bons, mas este estilo de filme não é estilo Blockbusters. O nome ao filme aqui no Brasil é “Um Pequeno Favor” tem referência do pedido de Emily para com Stephane olhar seu filho, enquanto ela tem um trabalho a fazer. E acaba desaparecendo. Vale apena assistir? Sim um suspense leve. Nota: 5

OK, this was a really interesting viewing experience for me. As it started, I was not impressed - it felt was over the top, almost cartoonish, both in plot and performance. But then the tide changed. I don't know if this is what the filmmakers had in mind, but I started viewing it as a satire of films like GONE GIRL, and I felt a groove, especially at the end when plot twist upon plot twist almost became laughable. And I realized this is kinda brave filmmaking, considering they're not necessarily winking at the audience. It reminded me of a Lifetime movie called A DEADLY ADOPTION with Will Ferrell and Kristen Wiig, which was played dead straight but was actually a remarkable satire of the kind of movie audiences confused it for being. It turned out to be a grand time and one of the nice surprises of 2018.

What happens when we do a simple favor for someone? It might turn into something far more deadly and unexpected Director Paul Feig who’s primarily known for big comedies takes a different approach with a suspense story based on the book by Darcey Bell Anna Kendrick plays Stephanie and Blake Lively plays Emily; one is a single mother who excels in cooking vlogs while the other is a successful, rich, beautiful fashion photographer with a husband and a son Stephanie in secret is more closed off acting mousey while Emily is more upfront with a blunt attitude cutting to the chase although it borders on psychotic even a bit catty The two of them become friends and when Stephanie is asked to pick up her son from school Emily all of a sudden goes missing What happened to her; did she run away, was she kidnapped, or did someone kill her? Stephanie starts to dig up answers and finds out more than she can handle The film is amazingly shot, brilliantly acted, and shocking while also being funny Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively bounce so wonderfully off one another It’s kind of a shame though Linda Cardellini is only in 1 scene There’s twist after twist too as the plot gets progressively darker Sure it’s a bit long but suspenseful and it sprinkles dark humor for a mom noir thriller Secrets are like margarine; easy to spread bad for the heart, you start digging around secrets you won’t like what you find, you have to go after the powerful ones otherwise they overpower you, everybody has a dark side they’re just better at hiding it than others I was pleasantly surprised by this one especially from Feig Both lead actresses are fantastic with a sharp, witty script involving sex, lies, murder, betrayal, secrets, and loyalty A clever game of cat and mouse that’s quite colorful aided by a French chic quality

This is one of those movies that I just kind of sat down to watch with very low expectations but them found myself absolutely engrossed. Anna Kendrick plays Stephanie, the kind of bright, apple-pie American mom who has a perfect kitchen and a buttoned-up personality that she just can't let drop. She produces her own vlog about home making and cooking. She's nervy, ditzy, highly-strung and ever so slightly sickening. One day on the school run, she meets Emily (Blake Lively) who is everything she is not. Cool, trendy, sophisticated and a bit of a bad girl, Emily has a spark that Stephanie finds appealing and the two strike up a friendship. Then, one day Emily disappears. Determined to find her, Stephanie starts digging into her friend's past and uncovers a dark and twisted tale. This is a great mystery movie that is sometimes goofy and comedic and at others tense and thrilling. I loved the juxtaposition of the styles and tones which were skilfully managed by Paul Feig's clever direction.
I love a good twist or more! This one had me guessing.
I absolutely adore Anna Kendrick. And her performance is, as always, top notch. But the story here is just boring as hell.

A Simple Favour brings a well-cast duo of leads in Kendrick and Lively, but their work goes to waste in a flaccid, tonal juggling nightmare devoid of inspiration and inorganically adding pulp at every turn. The script and final project rely solely on the audience developing an attachment with Kendrick's Stephanie, but her cute tambour and micromanaging personality render her unbearable for a mystery and her confident transformation towards the end even more so. Some of the comedy hits, but the added jokes can only prop up the unfortunate misfires masquerading as cleverness. Stephanie's excessive vlog interludes to pack the soundscape with even more content become tiresome by the halfway point. The soundtrack also failed to successfully create any mood except one of checking the time left on the film. All in all, A Simple Favour is certainly a unique project, although it serves as a warning for those to whom this would be enough.

They have nothing in common besides the fact that their children are in the same class, but somehow they become ‘friends'. Takeaways: The talented actors intensify this twist of comedy and mystery. A Simple Favor stars Anna Kendrick as a widow mother who befriends Blake Lively and they both have kids in the same elementary school. They become best friends and get to learn their deep darkest secrets. Henry Golding played Blake's husband who fell in love with Anna after Blake's mysterious death. This dark comedy has plenty of twists and turns directed by Paul Feig. You will enjoy the music, the clothes, the sarcastic tone and the fun twisted script. Definitely check this out.

"Gone Girl" rewritten as screwball comedy? Director Paul Feig starts "A Simple Favor" on the solid foundations of Anna Kendrick's comic skills, then paints more and more noir into the picture with the mysterious disappearance of Blake Lively's character. (Blake Lively plays the ultra cool girl. This is the only role allowed for tall, athletic California blondes.) But, as we delve into Blake's gothic backstory, the script keeps inserting laugh lines for Anna, and the ending doesn't even try to be serious. Worth seeing for the two leads and a hilarious collection of minor characters. Fans of Blake Lively can just sit quietly and drool. Fans of Anna Kendrick should watch the movie twice (I did) just to see how much extra expression and sight gags she crams into her role. Henry Golding is competent but over-shadowed. With the minor characters, Feig did a lot of inspired casting and directing, e.g. Linda Cardellini as the painter Diana Hyland, who makes her one scene spectacular.

A Simple Favour stars Anna Kendrick as Stephanie a nerdy, sweet, loving, stay at home who strikes up a new friendship with her sons friends mother, played by Blake Lively. Emily is a very successful working mother with an inappropriate manner and the polar opposite of Stephanies personality. None the less the vlogger and the PR rep become close friends, but once Emily goes missing Stephanie has a strange feeling about her disappearance and looks into her disappearance herself. This is my favourite Anna Kendrick film. She fits this role extremely well, her comedic ability paired with the thriller type story works amazingly. She has extremely good chemistry with Blake Lively who seems to have been born to play the role Emily. Both capture the attention of everyone with each scene they are in and when together they create a amazing duo. The movie is a little slow going as they develop these two characters, but once the investigation begins the film keeps you on the edge of your seat as secrets are revealed. Just when you think you've got these characters figured out they throw another curveball just to show you how unpredictable this film is. The film is very funny throughout but keeps the darker tone. As the story progresses you learn certain things that can make your skin crawl but then immediately after you'll laugh at a well timed joke. The film as I mentioned earlier is a little slow going in spots and when we get to the end there may have been a few to many twists which would've allowed the film to be better paced. Overall this comedy thriller will continuously surprise audiences as Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively show their acting ability in a extremely funny and unpredictable film. 9/10

I love it when a movie (the director really) can get the best performance out of everyone that is in this movie. Even if they are in it for only a few minutes. When I first saw the trailer for this movie, it looked very intriguing, but I was also worried that it would be another trailer that tells the whole plot of the film. I decided to take the risk anyway because I did really like the concept of the movie. Based off the book written by Darcey Bell in 2017, 'A Simple Favor' is about a mommy blogger named Stephanie (Anna Kendrick) who searches for her mysterious best friend Emily (Blake Lively) after she goes missing. I have to admit that I really liked this movie, more so than I thought it would. Based on the trailers and the overall concept, I thought it'd be good, but I didn't expect to like it as much as I did. The script, written by Jessica Sharzer, is a very well-written and clever script. It tells the story it's supposed to well, and there are many twists that keep the story running smoothly. While the plot twists didn't leave my mouth hanging open like most do, I still think they were good enough, and they weren't really wasted. I was also surprised at how many moments were funny. This wasn't the type of movie I thought would have humor in it because it's a thriller and drama. I figured humor would hurt the film, but it didn't. My only problem with the story, and I know it's just a movie and it's Hollywood, but everything that happens in the movie could never happen in real life. It's almost too good to be true. The cast performances were pretty good. Blake Lively was the standout, and her chemistry with Anna Kendrick was great and believable. They have a twisted storyline, and their performances help show it. Kendrick's character goes from a mom who always signs up for events at her son's school to investigating a missing person's case, and you can see her character change throughout the film. Lively's character is so mysterious and twisted that you can't make heads or tails on what's really going on until the climax of the film. And it's brilliant. Henry Golding as Emily's husband Sean Townsend was pretty good, but he was also somewhat mysterious as well. Based on the trailers and some moments in the film, you think he has something to do with it, so you become invested in his character. The costume design was interesting. Blake Lively wanted a look for her character that was iconic, and she was inspired by the film's director Paul Feig's look, so she decided to dress up like him. And ironically, it worked very well. In fact, that made her character even more mysterious and helped you wonder who she really was. While I think the plot was smooth and the pacing was fine, I do think that some sequences were just too unrealistic, and the timeline is sort of confusing. Does it take place over a certain matter of days, months, etc.? It was too unclear. Overall, this was a very good film. It's maybe not the kind of movie you have to watch more than once, but it's very enjoyable and very clever.

Blake lively really steals the show here within this movie. Her character is the only one that's intriguing and worth the watch. Anna on the other hand, brings a weirdness that I just wanted to run away from. Her characters secret was the most disgusting thing within the whole movie. Overall, the plot was too predictable (I always knew what was going to happen), I didn't agree with the way the writers tried to manipulate the audience (basically I was rooting for the characters the movie wanted you to dislike), the ending was very unrealistic, and Anna's performance was so awkward and disturbing it changed my opinion about her possibly forever. If it wasn't for Blake lively awesome performance (sorry they ruined your character) I would have given this movie zero stars
Mysterious and charming, this movie somehow fell under the radar but is worth the watch.

this kind of film genre is rare and kudos to Paul Feig for making this happen! Anna Kendrick was amazing in this as usual but more so than her other projects. Nice to see her tackle more diverse roles. Blake was amazing too and she and Anna really played off of each other so well!

There were times when something would happen and I would go "wait was that real?" and it's never explained. Emily and Stephanie feel more like ideas than actual characters. What tone does this film have? Is it an OTT thriller? Is it a dark comedy? Is it melodrama? I'm not sure, and I don't think it is either. It's one of those twisty turny plots where everyone has their own scheme going on, and it ends up with the three lead characters in a confrontation of sorts, but I felt like they'd all behaved so badly across the film that I didn't really want any of them to win. Anna Kendrick is pretty good at being pretty adorable in films. The danger with having an actor who is good at a particular thing is that sometimes their role gets skewed towards that particular thing in a way that damages the overall film (see also: Will Smith being funny in Suicide Squad). It happens here, with Anna Kendrick's character being SO cutesy and SO normal that when she needs to be more confident later on in the film it's such a 180 that it jars and she ends up coming across as cocky and gloating. Blake Lively is pretty good but a bit much as someone who is desperate to not be photographed, spotted or gain any notoriety, and yet wears a tuxedo to the park. And Henry Golding is as conspicuously inconspicuous as he was in Crazy Rich Asians. There was some fun stuff in here, but it drowned in all the other movies that were taking place at the same time.

The script seems to lack depth and moves through many different clichés throughout. There is a forced feel to the dialogue which seems to remove some of the intensity from the film, reducing it to an unrealistic film which reads like a TV drama or soap opera. Furthermore, the characters seem to represent familiar tropes – the cliquey parents provide a form of comic relief, but their over-the-top nature makes it feel forced rather than natural. This leads me onto my next observation – the script of the film in many areas feels confused, being tonally mismatched in places. By this I mean that it is not obvious what the script is going for – if it is trying to be self-deprecating and ironic, or if it is trying to provide genuine suspense and drama. The seeming self-deprecation of the film makes the, at times, contrived dialogue feel less like instances of bad writing, and more as a form of comedy and potential criticism to genre tropes. Nevertheless, it is very unclear, and in my opinion takes a lot away from the script – because it seems to be in conflict with itself. Is it an all-out thriller/mystery film, or is it a dark comedy? It could be both, but it does not succeed in both. Only at the end of the film do we see a true instance of this acidic wit and dark humour, which in itself is effective. However, it almost feels too late, and perhaps more could be integrated into the script throughout. A positive of the script is that it does not drag and is very fast moving – it takes almost no time at all to move into some form of conflict, and continues to do so throughout the film. So, in this sense, its pacing is good, and it does well to keep audience interest. However, with the fast-moving structure of the script comes a few issues. The script seems to move far too quick from one scene to the next, not allowing enough time for the audience to fully comprehend the significance of some scenes. This pacing also allows for little character development – we only truly see an arc with the main character, getting to know her development well. It is undoubtedly an entertaining film, and at many points, the mystery of the storyline distracts from the lazy dialogue. The script is good in this sense – it has an interesting and compelling storyline, but that is undermined at times through the dialogue and character believability.

One I would recommend.

I enjoyed this one quite a bit. A Simple Favor is a mystery, thriller that follows a single mom named Stephanie (Anna Kendrick) who while picking her son up from school meets Emily (Blake Lively) who is practically the opposite of Stephanie. Emily invites her over, so that their kids can have a play date. During this time Emily reveals that she works as a PR manager for a fashion company. Emily doesn't give one F about anyone it seems other than her son. She is foul mouthed, very powerful and finds that she likes Stephanie for her energy and stories. Soon enough the two become friends, but it seems that Emily is just having Stephanie watch her son. One day after Stephanie is watching the kids and Emily's husband Sean (Henry Golding) has to go to England for an emergency Stephanie realizes that it's getting late and Emily hasn't picked her son up. Two days pass and Sean comes home and the two decide to call the police. Soon enough a manhunt goes on to try and find Emily. During this time Stephanie starts looking into why Emily might have left and begins to dig up some very dark things about Emily's past. The movie has a pretty good pace. I enjoyed that it was quite funnier than I thought it was going to be. The mystery of it all is a fairly good twist, but I figured it out pretty quick. Kendrick is really good here as Stephanie and I especially enjoyed how dark her own past story is when it's revealed. I enjoyed this one and didn't think this would initially would be for me. I would recommend giving it a look.

Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively star in the odd dark comedy(?) A Simple Favor. When her best friend goes missing Stephanie uses her cooking video blog to launch her own investigation (with the help of her followers) and soon learns that her friend wasn't who she thought she was and that she faked her own death. Both Kendrick and Lively give strong performance (especially Lively) and have great chemistry together. The script is kind of weak and takes a while to get to the plot, but once the murder mystery kicks in the film starts picking up momentum and doesn't let up. And it's a good mystery, fully of suspense and intrigue. Plus there's some quirky black humor that's rather amusing. It has a few rough spots, but overall A Simple Favor is an entertaining and fun crime thriller.

This is one of my favorite films of the year. Something about the black comedy meets mystery/drama nature of this film works on every level. Kendrick, Lively, and Golding provide enthusiastic and intriguing performances. Kendrick portrayal of naivete and unabashed loyalty, and her character's transition in the third act are fantastic. Lively does a great job charming the audience with her sharp and abrasive performance. The combination of the elements really draws the audience in, and the remainder of the film does a great job toying with the audience's expectations without trying to get unnecessarily convoluted. I would definitely recommend checking it out.

A Simple Favor 8.2/10 From nearly start to finish this was just a fun, twisty thriller. This was extremely entertaining and there was rarely a moment I was not dialed in 100% to the movie. The duo of Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively drives this movie and are great (. There are also a lot of humorous minor characters in this movie that provided some extra timely humor relief. There were some twists I saw ahead of time plus the movie makes some interesting story choices (in my personal opinion) but those are minor flaws. There is some explicit material but not too much (it is R rated). Most of the twists you don't see coming and enjoy. This movie had a cool, stylistic noir flair to it that adds a nice edge to the movie, and the soundtrack fits pretty well. All in all, I've been looking forward to this movie for a few months because of Anna Kendrick/Blake Lively and because the mystery looked to be set up really well. It met my high expectations, highly recommend!

I truly believe this stylish genre-bender could have been a massive, sleeper hit had the marketing and title been a better service to the originality of the film. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively have magnetic chemistry and their performances along with Feig capably stretching himself as a director all come together to create a wholly unique spin on films like Gone Girl and The Girl on the Train. While I have no problems with the film's mix of tones, it does occasionally dip into campy a few times which feels too far out of place. A critical scene at the film's conclusion took me out of the fantastic build up to it. That said, I'm completely on board for more pairings of these two lead actresses and would not be surprised - or disappointed - if these specific characters return down the line.

Strengths: Anna Kendrick (Stephanie Smothers) continues to be a delight in everything she works in. She has become a solid choice to lead almost any comedy. I also appreciated the small role by Linda Cardellini (Diana Hyland), who proved she can nearly steal the show in just one scene. The first half or so of this movie is quite engaging. Weâ(TM)re introduced to the characters and the mystery, which is one that grabs you. You want to know just what the hell is going on, almost similar to the successful Gone Girl, but on a smaller and less serious scale. Weaknesses: Blake Lively (Emily Nelson) has gotten praise for her work here but I just donâ(TM)t see it. It often felt like she was trying too hard to be strange. It could partially be how the role was written, but I just never bought into her character. In fact, when she ultimately returns to the story a little over halfway through, the movie takes a nosedive. That should rev things up, but instead, the story goes off the rails. They try throwing way too much at the wall to give us twists and turns, yet it feels hollow and none of it really ever lands. Itâ(TM)s like it becomes a completely different movie that fails to capitalize on a mostly strong start. Overall: With a likable cast members and a great premise, I had high hopes for this. Instead, it gets bogged down by trying way too hard in certain aspects and the twists just never have a true impact.

A Simple Favor (4 out of 5 stars). A Simple Favor is a twisted, stylistic, and a fun mystery thriller film. It surpassed my expectations with its mystery plot, twist and turns with the story, and Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively performance was outstanding. The trailer did not show much besides Stephanie (Anna Kendrick) a single widowed mother who runs a vlog of cooking recipes. Who befriends with another mother Emily (Blake Lively) a busy director for a fashion company. There sons attend the same school. Stephanie high positive personality is trying to figure out Emily. She hates pictures being taken of her, she was amazed by the love affection her and her husband Sean (Henry Golding) share which makes them seem like the perfect couple. Until one day, Emily went missing. Were they all assume she went on a long business trip. When her work denies the trip. Stephanie becomes suspicious of her disappearance which she can not trust anyone. And trying to learn who Emily really is? Or figuring out Emily's past. The plot was surprisingly good. It is best to see without reading or hearing much more about the story without going into spoiler territory. There are twists and turns with the plot. It does have a campy fun direction from Paul Feig. Plus Anna Kendrick's down to earth and being super nice personality was a lot of fun to see. Then, Blake Lively's performance which was the opposite of her with a stuck up, rich personality. Seeing them both perform together was a lot of fun. Henry Golding was also good as well playing Lively's husband. A struggling writer with financial trouble. Overall, A Simple Favor is a good mystery thriller film. Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively were good with their characters. The plot had a twisted concept which does have a dark turn in tone and a fun campy direction. And Paul Feig managed to make those two different tones work well.
